questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of painless swelling in her external genitalia. On examination of the vulva, a tense, fluctuant mass is palpable at the posterior vaginal introitus, measuring approximately 3 cm in diameter (as shown below). No signs of inflammation are present. Which of the following is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Hot compress over the area and analgesics

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Marsupialization

Explanation:
Marsupialization is the most effective surgical treatment for Bartholin's cysts. It involves creating a permanent opening for drainage by suturing the cyst lining to the vaginal mucosa.

Bartholin’s Cyst

  • Bartholin's cyst forms when the duct or gland becomes obstructed, leading to fluid buildup.
    • Differential diagnosis:
      • Gartner duct cyst or GDC (located on the lateral or anterior wall)
      • Skene gland cyst (lateral to urethral meatus)
  • The cyst usually contains a clear, non-tender fluid—a product of the Bartholin's gland's secretion.
  • A physical examination typically reveals a soft, fluctuant swelling in the posterior part of the labia majora, often making the vulvar cleft appear S-shaped (a normal Bartholin's gland is not palpable during a physical examination)
  • They are managed by marsupialisation (recurrence on simple aspiration), followed by antibiotics.

Option A and B: Tetracycline suspecting chlamydial infection and ampicillin 500 mg 8 hourly are both management of Bartholin’s abscess.

Option C: Hot compress over the area does reduce the size of the cyst and analgesics have no application as Bartholin cyst is a painless swelling.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fever and intense pain in her vulvar region, reporting that she is unable to walk or sit comfortably. On examination, the physician discovered a red, edematous, unilateral swelling beneath the posterior half of the patient's labium majus which was tender on touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Bartholin's abscess

Explanation:

The intense pain, inability to sit or walk, fever, red and edematous skin, tenderness, and location of the swelling are all classic signs and symptoms of a Bartholin's abscess.

A Bartholin’s abscess occurs when the duct is blocked by fibrosis, causing exudates to build up inside the gland. If left untreated, the abscess may burst through the lower vaginal wall, leaving a sinus tract that periodically discharges.

Treatment of Bartholin’s abscess:

  • Rest
  • Analgesics to relieve pain
  • Daily sitz bath
  • Incision and drainage
  • Systemic antibiotics such as:
    • Ampicillin 500 mg orally every 8 hours
    • Tetracycline (in the case of chlamydia infection)

Option A) Bartholin’s Cyst is a painless swelling that does not cause fever and mostly remains unnoticed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with infertility. She reports a history of treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis in adolescence. What is the most likely route of spread of infection from the primary site to her pelvic organs leading to infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Hematogenous Spread

Explanation:
In about 90% of cases, pelvic organs are infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis secondarily through hematogenous spread from a primary site of infection, such as the lungs.

Other modes of transmission:

  • Direct spread of tuberculosis to the reproductive organs is possible from an infected adjacent organ, but this is less common than hematogenous spread.
  • Ascending spread of tuberculosis from the cervix to the fallopian tubes is rare.
  • Sexual transmission of tuberculosis to the reproductive organs is possible, but it is less likely than other routes of spread.
  • Lymphatic spread of tuberculosis to the reproductive organs from the peritoneum, bowel, or mesenteric nodes is possible, but it is less common than hematogenous spread

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for pelvic tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Fallopian tubes

Explanation:

  • The fallopian tube is the most common site of pelvic tuberculosis. From any of the primary sites, the pelvic organs are involved by hematogenous spread in about 90% of cases. The most common part involves the isthmus.
  • Option B: The endometrium is involved in 60% of cases. The infection is from the tubes either by lymphatics or by direct spread through continuity.
  • Option C: The ovaries are involved in about 30% of tuberculous salpingitis. The mode of spread is direct through continuity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Hysterosalpingography is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis
Infertility is the most common complication in untreated pelvic tuberculosis
Bilateral cornual block is a sign of genital tuberculosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation: 

  • About 70-80 percent of cases of genital tuberculosis have infertility, making it the most common complication of untreated TB.
  • Hysterosalpingogram is contraindicated in untreated genital tuberculosis due to the risk of reactivation of the lesion.
  • Hence, HSG is only done after completion of the entire course of Anti-tubercular drugs as a routine clinical workup in the investigation of infertility.
  • Bilateral cornual block on HSG is a sign for genital/pelvic tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of infertility and chronic pelvic pain. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is performed to evaluate her reproductive anatomy. Which of the following HSG findings is characteristic of female genital TB?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

Explanation:
Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is routinely performed as part of infertility investigations. However, it is contraindicated in confirmed cases of genital TB due to the risk of lesion reactivation.

Indicative Features of Pelvic Tuberculosis on HSG:

  • Dye extravasation through vascular or lymphatic channels
  • Distal tube obstruction

 

  • Tubes appearing rigid (lead-pipe) with nodularities


 

  • 'Tobacco pouch' appearance and beaded tube ends with variable dye filling density

 

  • Irregular uterine cavity outline, honeycomb appearance, or presence of uterine adhesions.


 

  • Beaded appearance of fallopian tubes
  • Tube coiling or calcified shadows
  • Bilateral cornual blockage
  • Tubal diverticula or fluffy tubal outlines

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with infertility and is diagnosed with tuberculosis (TB) of the fallopian tubes. Without antitubercular treatment (ATT), which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) can be done to check tubal patency.
Direct spread of TB may occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus.
Hematogenous spread will occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus.
TB will resolve on its own without treatment.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Direct spread of TB may occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus.

Explanation:

Tuberculosis (TB) of the female genital tract is usually secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body, most commonly the lungs.

The most common route of spread to the uterus is hematogenous (90% of cases).

  • Hematogenous spread: The bacteria travel via the bloodstream from a primary infection site, usually the lungs, to the uterus. This is the most common route because tuberculosis primarily affects the lungs and can disseminate to other organs through the blood.
  • Direct extension from the abdominal cavity and Lymphatic spread from the inguinal nodes: TB can spread through the lymphatic system or directly from the infected organs, but this is not the primary or most common route for genital TB.
    • Genital TB often starts in the fallopian tubes and can spread directly to adjacent structures, including the uterus.
    • This is due to the anatomical proximity and the continuity of the mucosal surfaces.
    • In the absence of treatment, TB can extend from the fallopian tubes to the endometrium, leading to endometrial TB. This form of spread is termed direct or contiguous spread and is a common pathway for genital TB progression.
  • Ascending infection from the lower genital tract: This route is more typical of bacterial infections like gonorrhea or chlamydia, not TB. TB bacteria rarely spread in this manner.

Other Options:

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) can be done to check tubal patency (False):

Performing HSG in the presence of active genital TB is contraindicated due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and spreading TB to other parts of the genital tract or the peritoneal cavity.

Hematogenous spread will occur from the fallopian tubes to the uterus (False):

While hematogenous spread is a primary mechanism for the initial seeding of TB to the genital tract, once TB has been established, the local spread from one genital organ to another is typically through direct extension, not hematogenous spread.

TB will resolve on its own without treatment (False): Antitubercular therapy (ATT) is essential to effectively treat TB, prevent its spread, and reduce the risk of severe outcomes and infertility.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and chronic lower abdominal pain for the past year. She mentions recent unintentional weight loss and occasional night sweats. Her menstrual cycles have been regular, but she has experienced heavier-than-usual periods over the past six months. Considering her symptoms and clinical history, the clinician suspects endometrial tuberculosis and decides to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosis.

Which is the best time to perform an endometrial biopsy to diagnose endometrial tuberculosis?

choices.text: Any time during the menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) During the late premenstrual phase

Explanation:

The optimal time to perform an endometrial biopsy for diagnosing endometrial tuberculosis is during the late premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle.

  • The tubercle is found in the basal layer of the endometrium and moves to the surface before menstruation. Following the shedding of the endometrium during menstruation, reinfection arises from the basal layer lesions or the fallopian tubes.

Layers affected: Endometrial tuberculosis typically affects the endometrial layer (60%) while sparing the myometrium.

Endometrial biopsy is done during the premenstrual period by D&C or hysteroscopy directed biopsy. Menstrual blood collected on the first day of menstruation (superficial layer is shed off) can also be used as a diagnostic sample because it may contain the bacilli responsible for the infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats, and was initially diagnosed as pulmonary tuberculosis. She now complains of menstrual irregularities and infertility. Upon further investigation, the following radiograph (shown below) is observed. What is the most likely explanation for her current condition?

choices.text: Direct extension of pulmonary TB to the uterus
Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB
Reactivation of latent TB in the uterus
Direct extension from peritoneum to the uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary genital TB due to hematogenous spread from pulmonary TB

Explanation:
This clinical scenario describes primary pulmonary TB leading secondarily to genital TB which causes complications such as Asherman’s syndrome.

Asherman's Syndrome is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands within the uterine cavity.

  • Endometrial ulceration due to TB uterus may lead to such adhesion or synechiae formation.

  • This may cause complications such as infertility, recurrent abortions, and secondary amenorrhea.

Genital TB usually spreads to the genital tract hematogenously from a primary focus, often the lungs.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Predominantly affects women of reproductive age group.
  • Primary or secondary infertility in 70-80% of cases of pelvic tuberculosis.
    • This may be due to tubal blockage/adhesions, endometrial destruction/synechiae formation, and implantation failure.
  • Menstrual abnormalities such as menorrhagia or oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea. Secondary amenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Tubo-ovarian mass
  • Constitutional symptoms like fever, loss of weight, malaise, anemia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of secondary amenorrhea and pelvic pain. She reports intermittent fever and significant weight loss over the past few months. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the lower abdomen, and an adnexal mass is palpated. Given these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Genital Tuberculosis

Explanation:
In this clinical scenario, the patient's history and physical examination findings raise high suspicion of genital tuberculosis (TB).

The key points include:

  • History of secondary amenorrhea and pelvic pain: These are common presentations in genital TB. Secondary amenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom.
  • Intermittent fever and weight loss: These systemic symptoms are often associated with TB in general.
  • Physical examination finding of adnexal mass and lower abdominal tenderness: These findings can suggest the presence of pelvic inflammatory disease, which can be due to genital TB.

Other points that raise suspicion of genital TB:

  • Chronic symptoms such as pelvic pain, menstrual abnormalities such as menorrhagia or oligomenorrhea.
  • Past history of TB or exposure to someone with TB.
  • Infertility (Primary or secondary)

Physical Examination Findings in Genital TB:

  • Tenderness in the lower abdomen, often with palpable adnexal masses.
  • Pelvic examination may reveal thickened tubes, nodularity, or mass formation due to tuberculous salpingitis or tuberculous tubo-ovarian abscess.

Option A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

  • PCOS is less commonly associated with significant weight loss, fever, or pelvic pain.Physical examination in PCOS may reveal features such as ovarian enlargement with multiple small follicles, but not typically palpable adnexal masses or tenderness.

Option B) Endometriosis:

  • Endometriosis can cause pelvic pain and infertility but is less likely to present with significant weight loss and systemic symptoms like fever.
  • Physical examination does not typically have palpable adnexal masses unless complicated by endometriotic cysts.

Option D) Ectopic Pregnancy:

  • Can present with pelvic pain and adnexal mass, but it wouldn't typically cause secondary amenorrhea and weight loss without severe complications like rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the role of ultrasonography (USG) and laparoscopy in the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis (TB) in women?

choices.text: USG can definitively diagnose genital TB by detecting specific tuberculous lesions in the pelvic organs.
Laparoscopy is mainly used to assess the extent of tubal damage in genital TB, and it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the affected tissues.
USG is more effective than laparoscopy in identifying tubal obstruction caused by genital TB.
Both USG and laparoscopy are equally effective in diagnosing genital TB and can be used interchangeably.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Laparoscopy is mainly used to assess the extent of tubal damage in genital TB, and it allows for direct visualization and biopsy of the affected tissues.

Explanation:

Laparoscopy is a crucial tool for diagnosing genital TB because it permits direct visualization of the pelvic organs, identification of lesions, and allows for biopsy collection and fluid aspiration for culture, which is essential for a definitive diagnosis.

USG, while useful for identifying abnormalities and guiding further investigation, cannot definitively diagnose genital TB or assess tubal damage as accurately as laparoscopy can (also assess feasibility of adhiolysis in severe distortion).

Investigations for Pelvic Tuberculosis:

  • Blood: Total leucocyte count and ESR may be raised
  • Mantoux test: less specific
  • Chest X-ray: To look for evidence of healed or active pulmonary lesions
  • Diagnostic uterine curettage
    • One part in normal-saline for:
      • Histopathological examination to detect the giant cell system.
    • One part in normal saline for:
      • Culture in Löwenstein-Jensen media
      • Identification of the acid-fast bacilli by Ziehl- Neelsen’s stain (AFB-microscopy)
      • Nucleic acid amplification
      • Guinea pig inoculation.
    • Liquid culture
    • Nucleic acid amplification test
    • GeneXpert (CBNAAT)
  • Biopsy
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG): In a proven case, HSG is contraindicated for the risk of reactivation of the lesion.
  • Imaging: USG, IVU, CT, MRI
  • Laparoscopy
  • Hysteroscopy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic pelvic pain, irregular menstrual cycles, and a two-year history of primary infertility. Upon evaluation, she is diagnosed with genital tuberculosis (TB). Considering the diagnosis, which of the following statements accurately describes the treatment approach for her condition, including both medical and surgical options?

choices.text: Medical treatment alone, consisting of antitubercular therapy for 6–9 months, is typically sufficient to restore fertility in all cases of genital TB.
Surgical intervention is usually needed in genital TB, as most cases do not resolve with antitubercular therapy alone.
Antitubercular therapy is the first-line treatment, but surgery may be necessary in cases of extensive adhesions, tubal blockages, or when there is a suspicion of an abscess.
The main treatment for genital TB is surgical removal of the affected reproductive organs, followed by a short course of antitubercular therapy.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Antitubercular therapy is the first-line treatment, but surgery may be necessary in cases of extensive adhesions, tubal blockages, or when there is a suspicion of an abscess.

Explanation:
Antitubercular chemotherapy is the treatment of the first choice. However, in cases where there are complications such as extensive adhesions, tubal blockages, or abscesses, surgical intervention may be necessary to address these issues and improve fertility outcomes. Surgery is not typically the first-line treatment but is considered when medical management alone is insufficient. IVF (in-vitro fertilization) with or without surrogacy can also be considered in case of severe distortion and thick adhesions.

RNTCP, Government of India,WHO National Strategic Plan (2019):

  • New cases:
    • (a)Initial phase: Four drugs are (WHO, RNTCP) used (2HRZE) daily for 2 months;
    • (b) Continuation phase: Three drugs daily for 4 months (4 HRE)
  • Previously treated cases:
    • Relapse, treatment failure, and lost in follow up—initial phase 4 drugs daily for 2 months (2HRZE) and three drugs daily for 4 months (4 HRE).
